alternatives.transcript: despite the significant progress however until recently there has been one serious impediment to improving the smolder resistance of upholstered furniture that could not be overcome despite intensive research the technology to consistently produce mold resistant cellulosic Fabrics was not known and certain Fabrics especially Cotton's would often not pay
pass the cigarette smoldering test

indeed as late as January of this year dr. Wilson reuse of the US Department of agriculture's cotton utilization laboratory stated in a published report that further research must be done to produce smolder resistant cotton upholstery Fabrics

mr. chairman I am pleased to report to you today that research by my company has developed substances that represent a major advance in the state of the art for rendering cotton Fabrics molded proof and resistant to open flame ignition we have shared this information with you fact using these substances class to upholstery Fabrics that currently ignite when subjected to the cigarette smoldering test will now either extinguish the cigarette or
upholstery fabric but not ignited

this treatment can be applied to Carpeting and draperies as well in addition these new treatments go beyond the original scope of class 1 Fabrics by now making these Fabrics resistant to open flame ignition as well as making them small to proof in fact as I have demonstrated to Congressman moakley our treatment will also render these Fabrics ignition resistant to open Flames such as matches and even a blowtorch

in short we have now developed a technology to make all upholstery fabric in this country Superior to class 1 that is resistant to ignition from an open flame or to a smoldering ignition Source such as a cigarette

there has been considerable concern in the country that regardless of the Technologies developed for new upholstered furniture the homes of America are filled with furniture that had not been treated to reduce its flammability in fact I can report that we have developed a method for applying a flame and smolder retardant in the home we recently have discovered how to penetrate water repellent finishes and had to retreat the Fabrics after the retardant is sprayed on

in the near future this new retardant will be available to the consumer for use on untreated upholstered furniture in the home after spraying on this product the consumers upholstery fabric will be flame retardant smolder resistant waterproof and oil and soil resistant
these new treatments have several distinct advantages they are low in cost in most cases less than 10 cents per yard they can be used with existing plant equipment

they have a minimal effect on the aesthetic properties of the fabric that is treated they produce a finish that is non-toxic safe and non mutagenic they use ingredients that are available domestically and are in abundance Supply and they can be applied in the fabric finishing plant or in the home

in short the past two months have seen a major breakthrough in the technology needed to produce Fabrics that will not be ignited by a burning cigarette or an open flame we now have plan trial scheduled with major upholstery fabric manufacturers and we'll have treated upholstery fabric available for further testing and evaluation within the next 30 to 60 days we hope to present for sale Fabrics treated with our system at the fall of 1983 Furniture Market

I am grateful for the opportunity to share with you these exciting new developments in methods of enhancing the flame retardancy and smolder resistance of upholstered furniture thank you very much doctor Spears I know you work for lorillard

the major other major competitor is the RJ Reynolds company and in December 19th 1982 the New York Times reported that the RJ Reynolds Tobacco Company adjusted the chemical composition of the cigarette paper in more cigarettes at more is the brand name of the cigarettes to prevent them from going out between Puffs now they have evidently been able to accomplish this this result with the that particular brand are you familiar with
processes and I cannot speak for RJ Reynolds I can however speak from point of view of our analyses of their products which we do on all of our competitors products

and we have seen no significant change in that product and certainly no deletion of additives or inclusion of additives from the period of time of its introduction until today or last week I guess is the last set of data I looked in are you saying the information is inaccurate that was reported in the New York Times that they added some chemical to the paper to to allow it to the cigarette to go out that would be my opinion it's inaccurate yes sir

mr. kornegay this legislation that's before us does not mandate a performance standard it doesn't mandate any regulation on the tobacco industry it simply calls for a government agency to do a study to see whether it's feasible to have the tobacco industry developed the technology and to use a performance standard that would extinguish the cigarette or to have it burn at a low enough flame so that it would not be as dangerous as
a source of ignition why don't you want just a study to take place

mr. chairman I all reading of them of the bill would indicate that you look at the findings in the Bell you look at the policy they've already found the fact in other words the Congress if this bill were adopted as his now written you'd be in effect requiring the cpsc to come up with a standard I'll challenge you to work with us to draft a bill that will not require them to come up

standard but to do an honest study and not be able to have a performance data unless they find that it's technically feasible practical economically and also they measure in the added health risk to the smoker what we agree with a bill like that if we have guaranteed that that study is framed in that way well of course I'd have to see see what we're going to come up with mr. chairman but further comment in reply to your question then when you move on into the rulemaking authority the commission is really doesn't

deal in terms of the study it talks about promote gating a performance standard for the cigarette as I understand it and the bill as I would support it would call for simply a study to find out whether it can be done before performance standard or any other regulation would be imposed if we assured you that that's exactly what the legislation did and assured your attorney who is now a whispering in your ear that's the fact that of the bill
why couldn't you support it

well first we obviously are have a different view of what the bill does and doesn't do another another substantial reason that we are opposed of course to refer this matter to the cpsc is the fact that they do not have as I thank mr. Statler acknowledged this morning in the commission the expertise to deal with this matter and as you've heard from dr. Spears you start tampering

with a cigarette it is a very highly Technical and complex undertaking they all the way they could do it would be to go out and employ other people to come in in my view what's wrong with that but then employ the experts let me get the testimony let them ashore that's us that in fact can't be done because we have enough people around here who say it can be done and if it can be done all the fire retardants on the furniture and upholstery all the the

public education campaigns as helpful as they are are not a full comprehensive way to prevent all these unnecessary deaths and injuries most of mr. chairman let me simply say that in this is a policy question for the Congress of course that it would be hoped by us that in arriving it that policy that Congress would consider of course those who say it can't be done and those who say it can be done but at the same

does it seem reasonable that your lobby ought to be able to prevent simply a study from going forward well of course mr. chairman I don't know how powerful the tobacco Lobby is I read I guess saying newspapers you do in many instances but I only answer I can give you that is that the tobacco industry at times is had accusations placed against it that really don't hold up when you come in and look at all of the

we have all that's dealing with understandable reasonable people we have a government agency that has the job of protecting the public from unsafe products and they can look at every product that's unsafe and evaluate whether there's anything they can do about it but they can't even look at your product to determine whether it's unsafe and whether something can be done to make it safer

you think about that well the guy was an act of the Congress and that's must look to them they are the ones who passed it and for reasons I'm sure satisfactory to themselves they decided that that was the way to do it satisfactory to you I didn't quarrel with it slyly is Chairman I find you a line of a question and intriguing

when I read page 4 lines 12 to 17 of HR 1880 and it's on 11 and bold type it says rulemaking section 4 A 1 the commission shall promulgate within 24 months after the date of enactment of this act final consumer product safety standards for cigarettes and little cigars which set performance standards ensuring that such cigarettes and little circle
cars have a minimum capacity for igniting smoldering upholstered Furniture and Mattress fires

now that says little bit more than a study to me I'd be happy to work with you this bill would have to get out of this subcommittee likes make sure that the legislation insist that the study show that it's technically feasible and they balance the risks and benefits and that we don't mandate any kind of performance standard if that language does does offense to that to claim then we'll change it and will work with you to change it well I look forward to working with you mr. education toward the prevention of the leading causes of fires today in this country we can do a better job of Code Enforcement as I discussed in my testimony we can do much better job of training the fire service in prevention and backing them up in that role we could have insurance incentives as the Europeans do to help prevent accidental fires as well as intentional fires let
